awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Fatigue Measurement Instrument
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will lead to development of a novel technology for monitoring operator alertness/drowsiness in trucks, buses, and trains. The device would also be ideally suitable for measuring fatigue of airport control tower operators and monitoring fatigue of other mission-critical personnel in civil and military operations.  Such automated alertness/fatigue monitoring technologies are expected to reduce significantly the 100,000 police-reported highway crashes that result in approximately 1500 fatalities annually as a consequence of drowsiness/fatigue factors.  Blink rate is a recognized putative noninvasive marker of central dopamine activity, so the novel technology would also provide useful neurophysiologic information on brainstem function sensitive to changes in brain dopamine concentrations such as Parkinson?s disease, Schizophrenia, Tardive dyskinesia, Tourette?s syndrome and others.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to create and test novel measurement device for direct of eyelid displacement in time to asses operator awareness fatigue status.  Operator fatigue degrades human performance because of lapses in vigilance and attention. The onset of fatigue remains difficult to detect, particularly in real life settings. Research shows that the measurement of PERcent of eyelid CLOSure (PERCLOS) is most sensitive to detecting operator fatigue. To assess operator awareness/fatigue status we propose to develop and test a novel measurement device for direct and precise assessment of eyelid displacement in near real time by means of electromagnetic induction.  The development will consist of proving the proposed concept?s feasibility by means of a "breadboard design." The production eyelid detection device (Phase II) would most likely use a micro-electronics Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) which combines the individual discrete components used in the prototype to miniaturize and reduce size and weight. The new device is to serve as an alternative to and a refinement of the existing PERCLOS metric for prolonged precise and non-intrusive measurement of alertness/fatigue without interference with an equipment operator?s daily activity.

por.por_cntn:
This report presents the outcome of the NSF SBIR Phase I project “Fatigue Measurement Instrument”. The instrument is purposed for detection of onset and monitoring of fatigue, and is based on measurements of the dynamic eyelid movements.

A prototype of this new instrument was built and tested in a study with 15 subjects. The results of the study demonstrated feasibility of the proposed technology.

The new technology explores assessment of dynamic eyelid movements through measurement of a weak and harmless oscillating electromagnetic field in the eyelid vicinity. An inductive wire-coil no-touch sensor, as well as a voltage controlled oscillator and interface electronics are installed on the eyeglasses frame. They are used to measure the changing electromagnetic field inductance as a result from the interaction between the basic oscillating magnetic field and the magnetic field generated in the eyelids. The original electromagnetic field generated by the wire coil induces small electrical currents in the eyelids, so-called eddy currents, which in turn produce the time-varying magnetic field modified by the eyelid movements.

Design of Proof-of-Concept Prototype

A proof-of-concept prototype was designed and tested in collaboration with LION Precision Inductive Inc., the world leader in eddy-current displacement sensors. The main achievements in the design of the prototype have been in identification of the resonant points that correspond to the physical geometric features of the eyelid that allow effective measurements of eyelid movements. With use of an impedance analyzer and a standard test coil, the resonant points were identified as 2.3 MHz, 16 MHz, 32 MHz, and 46 MHz.

It is assumed that while operating these eddy-current noncontact displacement position sensors in the proximity of one of these naturally occurring resonant points, the sensors are “in tune” with the structure of the eyelid, and therefore are able to detect the fine eyelid movements of blinking.

Use of a state-of-the-art commercial inductance-to-digital converter, LDC1000, and a low power, low cost microcontroller, MCU, from Texas Instruments allowed the prototype to be assembled on lightweight eyeglass frames and to detect and measure eye blinks in a highly sensitive and accurate way that was previously unavailable for fatigue detection systems.

Testing on 15 subjects has confirmed that eyelid movements can be measured and recorded by employing advanced resonance sensing electronics in the environment of an oscillating weak and harmless electromagnetic field. The chart below displays measurement of eye blinks of a person during a 20-second test. There are 5 blinks (represented by 5 profound dips in inductance) that are approximately 4 seconds apart.

The test has proved the feasibility of the proposed new technology to measure eye blink dynamics.

Outcome of the project for fatigue monitoring

The outcome of this project will be used for development of a new instrument for monitoring equipment operator fatigue in critical mission operations, including detection of vigilance impairment onset, both in civil and military applications.

Eyelid movement traits are highly informative in diagnosing the functional state critical for operator activity under monotonous conditions. It is known, for example, that the eye blink frequency increases beyond the normal rate in the fatigued state. Fatigue is one of the main factors that can impact the ability of pilots and air traffic controllers to maintain their performance over time. The instrument will also be perfectly suitable for measuring fatigue of drivers of trains, trucks and busses.

The new instrument will represent a noninvasive and simple approach for monitoring fatigue, and at the same time, it is expected to be on par with or to exceed the sensitivity and accuracy of existing fatigue measurement systems. It will serve as an alternative to the PERCLOS system, which uses a combination of a source of infrared light and a video camera to measure the portion of time when a subject’s eyes are closed, and is currently the most utilized technology for measuring fatigue.

In addition, the new proposed instrument will have the advantage of being insensitive to lighting and operator head movements, which represent limitations of the most currently existing methods for assessment of fatigue.

 

Outcome of this project for medical applications

It has been established that dopamine activity correlates directly with blink rate. That is why blink rate is considered a potential noninvasive marker of central dopamine activity. Blink rate was assessed in a series of clinical studies of Parkinson’s disease (PD), Huntington’s disease, dystonia and schizophrenia. The results showed, for example, that the normal control rate of 24 blinks per minute was significantly higher than the rate of 12 blinks recorded in medication-free PD patients. The reduced blink rate signifies a worsening of PD, and a significant increase in blink rate in patients treated with a dopamine agonist may be a harbinger of agonist-induced dyskinesia.
